title: Jack Huber
text:
I am Senior Clinical Data Analyst for the Clinical Pharmacy team of Providence Swedish Medical Center in the Puget Sound area.
I am an Adjunct Instructor for the Doctor of Educational Leadership program in the School of Education at Gonzaga University.
I am also a Research Associate for the Social & Economic Sciences Research Center at Washington State University.

title: Current projects
text:
Outcomes of Monoclonal Antibody Use in Patients with COVID-19 - a propensity-matched comparison of the effect of monoclonal antibodies on 28-day rehospitalization and mortality in 21,139 outpatients with mild-to-moderate COVID-19 infections who presented to Swedish Medical Center emergency departments from 2021 to 2022
Predicting Mortality in Patients with Necrotizing Fasciitis: A Machine Learning Study - Unsupervised and supervised models to predict mortality in 158 patients diagnosed with necrotizing fasciitis (flesh-eating bacterial infections) at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston from 2008 to 2019
Predicting Mortality in Heart Failure Patients Admitted to ICU - a logistic regression analysis of mortality in 1,177 adult heart failure (HF) patients admitted to Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston from 2008 to 2019

title: Current projects
text:
Religion

Tableau visualizations
Retention, Transition, and Disaffiliation from American Christianity: Trend Data from the General Social Survey, 1972-2018 - A nifty tool for exploring trends of retention and transition in American religious affiliation as well as a specific focus on disaffiliation from Christianity, based on data are from the General Social Survey, 1973 to 2018.
America’s Changing Religious Traditions - A Sankey diagram visualization of data from the Pew Research Center’s 2015 “Changing Religious Landscape” study


In-progress
Validity Evidence for the Spiritual Harm and Abuse Scale (SHAS) - Koch and Edstrom (2022) developed a scale of spiritual harm and abuse by religious leaders. Here I plan to use the Rating Scale Model to examine the technical quality of the scale for use in research. 
Validity of a Scale of Spiritual Well-Being - The Pew Research Center 2015 Changing Religious Landscape survey included four items that could form a scale of spiritual well-being. I plan to use classical test theory and item response theory to assess the technical quality of this scale for use in research. 
Coping during the COVID-19 Pandemic 
A Closer Look at Glossolalia

title: Jack Huber
text:
I’ve gone by different titles – sociologist, data analyst, psychometrician, assessment director – but the common thread of my career has been data. For over 20 years I’ve applied tools from measurement, statistics, and empirical research design to help leaders of organizations use data to make more informed decisions.
My background is sociology. My undergraduate work at Arizona State (B.A., 1993) was in sociology, as was my early graduate work at Virginia Tech (M.S., 1997). Back then I was interested in the sociology of religion and politics, and I found inspiration and guidance in the work of Fr. Andrew Greeley. The topic of my thesis was the political mobilization of Evangelical Protestants. It was a statistical analysis of data from a national survey.
In 2000, I went to work in public education. I landed a job in the central office of a school district as its first Student Learning Data Analyst, and there I spent six years helping administrators and teachers interpret data from student achievement tests. This was a time of education reform at the federal and state levels which created mounting pressure at the local level to use student achievement data to make educational decisions. In that time I completed a doctorate in educational psychology with a specialization in measurement and cognates in motivation and educational leadership. My dissertation looked at high school teachers’ use of student achievement data. This project, too, was a statistical analysis of data from a survey.
Upon completing my doctorate I went to work in administration, where, for ten years, I was Director of Assessment for several school districts. In that role I oversaw administration of high-stakes testing, implemented district tests and data warehouses, analyzed and reported results of all student data, evaluated instructional programs, and did professional development on all aspects of data. On the side I did validity studies of my work in assessment, the results of which I presented at conferences and published in journals. I was active in two professional associations. At the state level, as a board member of the Washington Educational Research Association (WERA) I helped plan conferences, edit newsletters, and award research grants; and at the national level, I served terms as Secretary and President of the National Association of Test Directors (NATD).
Since 2017, I have helped lead data-based decision-making for the Catholic schools in western Washington, the pastoral planning department of the Archdiocese of Seattle, and now the pharmacy departments of the Swedish Medical Center hospitals in my region. For ten years I have been a Research Associate providing psychometric expertise for the Social & Economic Sciences Research Center (SESRC) at Washington State University, and this fall marks my second as an Adjunct Instructor for Gonzaga University co-teaching courses on analysis of quantitative data to doctoral candidates in the Department of Educational Leadership & Administration.
On the side I continue to study data from large surveys. I have created several Tableau workbooks for exploring data on American religious identification, and I am currently studying the validity of data from a recently developed clinical scale of spiritual harm and abuse.

title: Current Projects
text: My scholarly research interests are measurement and American religion. I also study theology and spirituality.

title: Current Projects
text:
Work in Progress
Validation of the Spiritual Harm and Abuse Scale with the Rating Scale Model - a validity study of data from a nascent scale of spiritual abuse

title: Current Projects
text:
Tableau Visualizations




Retention, Transition, and Disaffiliation from American Christianity: Trend Data from the General Social Survey, 1973-2018
A set of Tableau visualizations for exploring trends of retention in, and transition between, religious traditions, and disaffiliation from Christianity among American adults, based on 45 years of data from The General Social Survey



America’s Changing Religious Traditions
A Tableau visualization of retention in, and transition between, religious traditions among American adults, based The Pew Research Center’s 2015 “Changing Religious Landscape” study



50 Years of Change in the American Catholic Church
A series of Tableau visualizations of trends in American Catholic clergy, parishes, schools, hospitals, and more, based on data from The Center for Applied Research in the Apostolate (CARA)
